sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Paris you've most likely seen or maybe even drank from one of these iconic Wallace fountains. This year the French capital celebrates the 150th anniversary of the famous network of clean drinking water.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In 1876, British philanthropist Sir Richard Wallace inherited a large fortune and donated 50 fountains to the city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: His sketches were handed to a sculptor from Nantes for the final product to be made in cast iron and were around 3 meters tall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They come in all shapes and sizes, but the most common model is this one, with Greek caryatids.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: These caryatids are allegories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They represent qualities praised by Richard Wallace and the philanthropists of the time, namely goodness, charity, simplicity, and sobriety.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We were able to show in particular that the fountains had been installed both in privileged areas of passage for the people who need these fountains the most, like for labourers, but they were also installed near places of celebration, like near drinking establishments, to try and encourage people to be more sober.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Today there are more than a hundred of them scattered around Paris and a few hundred more around the world in cities such as Barcelona and Jerusalem.
